Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English 
with Jennifer. It's tax season! Ah!

One thing I don't like about being an 
independent online teacher is filing

taxes because it's rather complicated. Would you 
like to know more about paying taxes in the U.S.?

Or do you already know a lot and 
think you can pass a short quiz?

Well, let's start our lesson and I'll go over 
some basic vocabulary related to taxes. Now,

I'm not an expert on the subject, but 
I'll explain things as I understand them.

What do we call the tax that people pay on the 
money they earn, meaning the money they make?

C. Income tax. Our income is what 
we earn. It's the money we make.

"Earn" is the verb. "Earnings" 
are what we receive.

"Wages" refers to a fixed amount of money that 
you get for work that you do within a day, a week,

or a month. People can also make a profit. That's 
the money they gain from a sale of some kind.

For example, people can make a 
profit from the stock market.

There are different ways to earn income, but 
our income is taxed. The government takes a

percentage of our earnings so that it can 
pay for all kinds of government expenses.

"Tax" can be a noun or a verb. We pay 
taxes. The government taxes our income.
They tax our earnings. Our earnings are taxed.

"Expenses" refers to what we spend our money 
on. In the U.S., college is a big expense.
And at the federal level, I'd say defense

is a big expense. The government 
spends a lot of money on the military.

Who exactly collects our taxes? The 
IRS. The Internal Revenue Service.
What is true about sales tax in the U.S.?

B. Most but not all 50 states have sales tax. 
This is an additional amount of money we pay

when we purchase things, like food. But other 
stores besides grocery stores can have sales tax.

Actually, not all grocery stores have sales 
tax. It depends on the state. In some states,

groceries are not taxed. These 
items are exempt from sales tax.

Let's play a little shopping game. 
At a Massachusetts grocery store,
which of these items have sales tax?

Well, we'll just draw a line 
straight down the middle,

and then we'll have two groups. On the left 
are things that are exempt from sales tax.

Milk, bread, fruits, and vegetables these 
things are not taxed. But hot prepared foods

at a grocery store are taxed. Pet food is also 
taxed. Vitamins, non-prescription medicine,

paper goods, and household cleaning supplies 
all have sales tax in Massachusetts.
What other items are tax-exempt?

Most clothing. Not appliances, not cars, 
and not food from a restaurant. Thankfully,

clothing is usually tax-free. Where I live, a 
lot of people head north to New Hampshire for

tax-free shopping. That's because New Hampshire 
doesn't have sales tax, and Massachusetts does.

Sales tax varies across the 
country. It can be high or low.

Massachusetts levies a statewide tax of 
6.25%. "Levy" means "collect." Levy a tax.

The other two kinds of taxes that I listed are 
less important for this lesson, but very briefly,

estate tax is the tax on a person's estate when 
they die. All the things a person owns a value is

their estate. It's rather complicated, so I'm not 
even going to attempt to explain this in detail.

Excise tax is tax on a specific good. It can be 
paid at the time of sale, like on cigarettes.

Or it could be paid annually. In 
Massachusetts, we have excise tax on our cars.

If a family has two cars, they pay excise tax on 
each car. Thankfully, the longer you own a car,

the less excise tax you pay. A newer more 
expensive car will lead to a higher excise tax.
When must Americans pay their taxes?

B. But maybe i should have included a fifth 
option of "never," but I'll talk about getting

in trouble with the IRS a bit later. The answer 
is by April 15th, so right now it's tax season.

It's not fun unless you're an accountant. I sure 
like the December holiday season a lot more.

During tax season, we get ready to file 
our taxes. We file our tax returns.

There are forms we must fill out. There are 
documents we must collect. If you work for a

company, your employer usually sends your 
tax forms in January. This is a W-2 form.

I'd like to give you a quick look at a W-2 
form. When you file your taxes, the IRS will

ask for your Social Security number (SSN). If 
you don't have a valid Social Security number,

you can file with what's called an Individual 
Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN). On a W-2,

your wages tips and other compensation need 
to be listed. A bit later, I'll explain about

money withheld and specifically 
Medicare and Social Security.

If you're an independent contractor like me, you 
get a bunch of 1099 forms from people who paid you

in the previous calendar year, so you have to keep 
track of all your earnings and business expenses.

When you do freelance work, you might 
have a lot of miscellaneous earnings,

that is money from different 
jobs and different sources.

Thankfully, we can file our 
tax returns electronically

online, so it's not difficult 
to meet the April 15th deadline.

A deadline is the due date. We must file 
our tax returns no later than April 15th.

Here's a quick look at a 1099. As I mentioned, you 
can have income from different sources. A person

can have income from rent if they own real estate. 
You can earn royalties if you've published a book,

for example. The form is quite short, but a 
taxpayer can have several of these 1099 forms,

and there can be numerous business expenses, so 
the process of filing can be quite complicated.

In the U.S., does everyone pay the 
same percentage of their income?

D. No, we don't all pay the same percentage. 
The U.S. has a progressive tax system.

It's based on a person's ability to pay. 
The more you earn, the more you pay.

Higher earners pay a higher rate. 
Lower earners pay a lower rate.

The system divides us into groups 
called tax brackets. If you earn little,

like ten thousand dollars a year, you fall into 
the lowest tax bracket and pay ten percent. If

you're lucky enough to earn well over five hundred 
thousand dollars a year, you fall into the highest

tax bracket and pay thirty-seven percent. That's 
if you're single -- one person, unmarried.

So, a single person who earns less 
than ten thousand dollars a year

will fall into the lowest tax bracket, but another 
person may be filing as head of the household.

That means the person has a family. The 
person has dependents, people who depend

on him or her financially. That could be a child 
or another relative who lives in the same house.

So, this head of the household may earn thirteen 
or fourteen thousand a year, but because they have

dependents, they also fall into the lowest tax 
bracket. Married people usually file jointly,

meaning together. So, if a married couple earns 
less than nineteen thousand dollars a year,

they too will fall into the lowest tax bracket. 
So, there are different factors to consider.

Some argue that a flat tax system is fair and a 
lot simpler. Flat tax means that everyone pays

the same rate, like ten or twenty percent. What 
do you think? Is one system better than the other?

Does it depend on the country? Let me 
know your thoughts in the comments.
How do people pay their taxes?

D. People pay their taxes different ways because 
people receive their money different ways.

When you get hired at a company, you 
fill out a tax form called a W-4.

This tells your employer how 
much money should go to the IRS

each time you get paid. In other words, money 
is withheld from your paycheck. It's not a bad

thing because if it turns out you overpaid, 
you get a tax refund. You get money back.

The IRS will either mail you a refund check 
or deposit the refund into your bank account.

And if not enough money was withheld, 
then you owe that money by April 15th,
but it probably won't be a lot.

Let's take a quick look at a W-4. It's officially 
called an employee's withholding certificate,

and it tells you the purpose. You 
complete the W-4 so that your employer

can withhold the correct federal income tax 
from your pay. It's pretty straightforward.

You fill out your name and address 
Social Security number or tax ID number,

and then you state your status: single, married, 
head of household. There are steps to follow,

and at the end, you sign and date it 
and return the form to your employer.

Many freelancers pay quarterly taxes. 
They estimate how much they'll earn

within the year, and then they make 
a tax payment every three months.

Again, if they overestimate, they'll get a refund. 
If they underestimate, then they owe money.

If you don't make those quarterly 
payments, it's still okay.

You make a single payment before April 15th, 
but you'll likely have to pay a penalty.

You need good financial planning because if 
you owe taxes and then can't pay that money

by April 15th, you incur tax debt. "Incur" is a 
formal way of saying "have." You cause yourself

to be in debt. You have debt. That's not good. 
Tax debt can be a big problem for some people,

but the IRS will allow people to pay 
what they owe little by little. You

can request an installment agreement, so 
you can pay your taxes in installments.

Okay. Let's do a super quick check 
because we're at the halfway point.

What do you remember? What kind of 
tax might you pay in a U.S. store?

Sales tax. What kind of tax do 
people pay on their earnings?

Income tax. Which agency 
collects taxes in the U.S.?

The IRS. If there are products that are not 
taxed in a store, how can we describe them?
We can say they're tax-free. They're tax-exempt.

They are exempt from tax. They're not 
taxed. Okay. American taxpayers submit

W-2 forms and 1099 forms. When must they 
file their taxes? When's the deadline?

April 15th. 2022 is an exception due to a holiday, 
but the traditional deadline is April 15th.
What kind of tax system does the U.S. have?
A progressive tax system. What's the alternative?
A flat tax system.

When taxpayers file, what kind of status 
might they have? Can you name at least two?

Single, head of household, married filing 
jointly, and another option, by the way,

is married filing separately. What 
makes a person "head of household"?

Dependents. If you pay too much in 
advance, what do you get back from the IRS?
A tax refund.

Last question. If you fail 
to pay, what do you incur?
Tax debt. Okay. Let's go on.

Is having dependents the only factor 
that lowers the amount you owe the IRS?

B. No. A qualifying dependent makes 
a taxpayer the head of a household.

Because you have to provide for another person 
financially, you receive a standard deduction.

That means you can deduct or subtract a certain 
amount of money from your gross income, that

is, your total earnings. The IRS allows different 
deductions. Another example of a deduction is

a donation you make to a charity: a charitable 
donation. After you calculate all your deductions,

you arrive at your adjusted gross income 
(AGI). This is your taxable income.

There are also tax credits. A tax credit is 
subtracted from the money you owe the IRS.

You might get a tax credit if you 
buy an electric car, for example.

Families can get help with the Child Tax 
Credit. Parents receive a tax credit for each

child they have, but higher earners receive 
less of a credit. If you're self-employed,

you have business expenses, and you're allowed 
to list these expenses on your tax return.

In other words, you can 
write off certain expenses,

like use of the internet and travel expenses. 
This helps adjust the amount of money you owe.

What happens if you don't 
file your income tax return?

I'm going to say the best answer 
is B, but it's rather complicated.

You won't go to jail for not filing 
your taxes, but if the IRS finds out,

they can take action against you. Part of 
the job of the IRS is to collect back taxes,

the money that people owe from the years 
they didn't pay. The IRS will also calculate

a new sum that the person owes, including 
penalties and interest on the amount not paid.

So, failing to file and failing to pay can lead 
to trouble. One factor is how much you earned.

If you earned ten thousand dollars back in 2000 
and didn't file, you'll probably be okay. But if

you earned over eight hundred thousand dollars in 
2000 and you didn't file, good luck hiding that!

What happens if you lie or cheat 
when you file your tax return?

C. If you try to avoid paying what you owe, if 
you deliberately try to hide how much you earned,

that's called tax evasion and it's a crime. You'll 
pay a high penalty, and you may face jail time.

Basically, everyone needs to 
remember that tax contributions

are important. Paying taxes is a civic duty. 
It's our responsibility as members of society.

We pay into the system so that we can benefit 
from it. Who actually files the tax returns?

E. Taxpayers or accountants. If you only have 
a W-2, if you're single without dependents,

and your finances aren't complicated, you can file 
on your own. It's not that difficult. There's even

software to guide you through the process. If, 
however, you have your own business, you have

multiple sources of income, you have dependents, 
if your family circumstances have changed,

you may choose to hire a Certified Public 
Accountant or CPA. This person can help you

file your tax returns and also help if you get 
audited. If the IRS has reason to believe that

you made mistakes on your tax returns, they can 
officially investigate your financial accounts.

This is called an audit. You can be 
audited. You can get audited by the IRS.

What other taxes do Americans 
pay besides federal income tax?

E. When we file our taxes, we're responsible 
for paying federal, state, and local taxes.

And each household is different. Some people 
own property, so they pay property taxes.

Remember how I talked about money 
withheld from someone's paycheck?

It's very common to have Medicare and Social 
Security withheld as well. A percentage of our

earnings goes to Medicare. That's health care 
for the elderly and people with disabilities.

A percentage also goes to Social Security. 
That's a program that provides for the

elderly and people with disabilities -- 
people who cannot work to earn wages.

Final quiz. Let's see what you 
remember from the second half.
What lowers the amount of your taxable income?
A deduction.
What lowers the amount you owe in taxes?
A tax credit.
What can an independent contractor write off?

Business expenses. If a person hides how much they 
earn in order to avoid taxes, what crime is that?

Tax evasion. If the IRS thinks you made errors and 
wants to investigate, what's the process called?
An audit. You can get or be audited by the IRS.
Who can help you prepare and file your taxes?
A CPA, a Certified Public Accountant.

Why is additional money withheld from a 
paycheck? What two programs do taxpayers pay for?
Medicare and Social Security.

We've arrived at the end of 
the process. This is a 1040,

the form that taxpayers submit along with their 
w2 or 1099 form. You can see the first field

is where we indicate our filing status. There's 
a field for your deductions and dependents,

and then comes the fun math section. This 
is why many people hire an accountant. Now,

this is only one version of the 1040, 
and other forms might be required.

Whew! Taxes are complicated. Do you file your 
own taxes? Do you find it easy to handle your

own finances or do you turn to others for 
advice and support? Some people love numbers

and the world of accounting. Thank goodness 
for those people. They pay attention to detail,

and they understand finances. Well, here's a 
final challenge for everyone. Can you explain the

tax system in your country? How do taxes work? 
You can put your explanation in the comments.

We'll end here. Please like the video if 
you learned something new and share the

lesson with others who can benefit from it. As 
always, thanks for watching and happy studies!
